node.title: Napier Covid-19 confusion caused by 'system failure' - Bloomfield
node.description: Health officials thought a man diagnosed with Covid-19 in Napier was in Auckland.

node.title: Exhaustion, strategic choices behind NCEA exam decisions
node.description: Auckland teenagers are citing exhaustion, busy-ness and strategic thinking as reasons for skipping some or even all of their NCEA exams.

node.title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Dancing With the Stars’ and the Soul Train Awards
node.description: The season finale of “Dancing With the Stars” airs on ABC. And Tisha Campbell and Tichina Arnold return to host the 2021 Soul Train Awards on BET.

node.title: Covid-19 update: 205 new community cases of Covid-19, one death
node.description: There have been 205 new community cases of Covid-19 reported in New Zealand today and a person has died.

node.title: The Liberals' own faceless men find the perfect time to make Morrison's job hell
node.description: Two Liberals senators who few in the party expected to be elected have found themselves holding the Prime Minister's legislative agenda just months out from an election, potentially making Scott Morrison's job even harder, writes political correspondent Brett Worthington.

node.title: Afghan group given second chance at immigration after High Court review
node.description: A group of Afghan people trying to escape the Taliban have won a High Court judicial review to have their applications to come to New Zealand revisited.

node.title: St Basil's aged care manager accused of failing to pass on keys, passwords as outbreak struck
node.description: The manager of Melbourne's St Basil's aged care home is accused of failing to pass on clinical notes, keys and computer passwords to the staff who came in to run the facility as a deadly COVID-19 outbreak took hold.

node.title: Investors swindled out of millions by Sydney businesswoman a step closer to getting money back
node.description: A court finds missing Sydney businesswoman Melissa Caddick broke the law by operating without the required financial services licence, ordering her company be wound up and permanent receivers appointed.

node.title: The pressures of small-town policing and on sole-charge officers
node.description: An Independent Police Conduct Authority (IPCA) report has found major issues with the resourcing of small community police stations. Audio

node.title: Covid-19 updates for 22 November - as it happened
node.description: More than 1.1 million digital Covid-19 vaccine certificates have now been created and the Ministry of Health says the system has been going smoothly.

node.title: Concern 200ha of council land could go with Three Waters assets transfer
node.description: South Wairarapa locals are worried they could lose land they've bought and paid for when the government's Three Waters reforms kick in. South Wairarapa locals are worried they could lose...

node.title: Your Monday Briefing
node.description: The reinstatement of Sudan’s prime minister.

node.title: SA Premier apologises after surge in applications to enter SA crash website
node.description: SA's website for entry assessment is inundated with more than 25,000 applications ahead of the state borders opening at 12:01am on Tuesday.

node.title: Waukesha Closes Schools, Downtown Roads After Parade Tragedy, Victims' Families Being Notified
node.description: While many search for answers in Waukesha, the school district has already declared that school will not take place on Monday.

node.title: What is sustainable when it comes to fashion? Europe's new laws rate synthetics over natural fibre
node.description: Tackling "greenwashing" in the fashion industry, Australian wool and cotton growers have joined forces to take on Europe's new textile labelling laws over the very definition of sustainable.

node.title: Worker dies on building site in Perth's southern suburbs
node.description: A man dies while working on a residential building site in North Coogee in Perth's south, after he is believed to have been struck on the head.

node.title: Whangārei: Submissions overwhelmingly against Oruku Landing events centre
node.description: Whangārei District Council's proposed Oruku Landing convention and events centre has had a big thumbs down from submitters - on the eve of the council deciding on whether to go ahead with the…

node.title: Peng Shuai talks to IOC
node.description: Chinese tennis star Peng Shuai has had a video call with the president of the International Olympic Committee and told him she was safe and well.

node.title: Black Caps well beaten at Eden Gardens
node.description: The Black Caps have been swept by India in the T20 series with the tourists unable to offer much in the third and final game in Kolkata.

node.title: ‘Insecure’ Recap, Season 5, Episode 5: Out of Control
node.description: As Molly deals with a family emergency, Issa finds a new relationship moving faster than she planned.

node.title: Milwaukee Dancing Grannies Asks for Prayers After Waukesha Parade Tragedy, Say Members 'Impacted'
node.description: A car plowed through a Christmas Parade in Waukesha, Wisconsin, on Sunday, injuring at least 23 people including children.

node.title: Foreign Minister heading to the US
node.description: The Foreign Affairs Minister is heading for Washington DC for meetings with US Secretary of State Antony Blinken after visiting Expo 2020 in Dubai.

node.title: 'Our boys are struggling' - Migrant dads desperate to be reunited with family
node.description: Fathers separated from their children by border restrictions are calling for the government not to forget their plight.

node.title: ‘Succession’ Recap, Season 3, Episode 6: Pretenders to the Throne
node.description: Kendall had hoped to be the kingmaker, but we all know whom that role belongs to.

node.title: 'We miss you Mommy': What is happening with Monaco's Princess Charlene?
node.description: Princess Charlene's long-awaited return to Monaco is cut short ahead of major celebrations in the wealthy nation. Here's what we know about it.

node.title: Sudan's military reinstates ousted civilian PM
node.description: Sudan's civilan Prime Minister has appeared on TV to sign a new power-sharing agreement with coup leader General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan.

node.title: Justin Bieber urged to cancel concert in Saudi Arabia in protest over human rights record
node.description: Pop star Justin Bieber faces growing calls to cancel a concert in Saudi Arabia over the Kingdom's human rights record. The fiancee of slain Saudi critic Jamal Khashoggi joins a chorus of voices urging him not to perform.

node.title: Schoolies 'aren't as drunk as they used to be', authorities say
node.description: Police say this year's crop of school leavers are "actually the best", with bad behaviour of all kinds down on previous years and "toolies" making up the majority of the weekend's arrests.

node.title: FedEx workers locked out as industrial dispute intensifies ahead of Christmas delivery rush
node.description: FedEx locks workers out as an ongoing industrial dispute threatens parcel deliveries in the run-up to Black Friday sales and Christmas.

node.title: First-term MP to replace Vickie Chapman as Attorney-General in SA Government
node.description: Adelaide Hills backbencher MP Josh Teague will be sworn in as South Australia's Attorney-General tomorrow, replacing Vickie Chapman.
